citations.narrative:
There are three primary enclosures that are currently housing 15 puppies and 2 adult dogs that contain carpet squares in
disrepair with frayed edges and long strands of carpet fibers. Two enclosures housing an adult female dog with 5 puppies
in each enclosure has carpet in the whelping box that has been torn and damaged by the dogs. These carpets have long
strands of fiber in the torn areas that are easily accessible by the juvenile dogs. Frayed edges and long fiber strands can
be injurious to the dogs as they could ingest the material or cause entrapment of the juvenile dogs. All surfaces must be
maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities - including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and
objects within the facility - that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by 16 December 2025

The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for sampling and testing of intestinal parasites. The facility has
not performed fecal sampling according to the schedule described in the program of veterinary care. The last recorded
results for fecal sampling provided by the facility were reported on 18 January 2024. The facility representative stated this
is usually performed during the annual kennel exam but could not provide a record of the sampling in 2025. APHIS
personnel spoke with the office of the Attending Veterinarian who stated no fecal sampling was conducted in 2025. The
program of veterinary care states fecal exams will be performed annually on 10% of the animals for intestinal parasites.
Failure to follow the parasite control program approved by the attending veterinarian may not properly protect the dogs
from parasites and may allow illness to go undetected and untreated, which may cause pain and unnecessary discomfort
to the dogs. The facility must follow the parasite control testing schedule approved by the attending veterinarian to protect
the dogs from parasites and other pests (worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) and have the dogs tested annually.
Correct by 31 January 2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.1(c)(2) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are three primary enclosures that are currently housing 15 puppies and 2 adult dogs that contain carpet squares in 
disrepair with frayed edges and long strands of carpet fibers. Two enclosures housing an adult female dog with 5 puppies 
in each enclosure has carpet in the whelping box that has been torn and damaged by the dogs. These carpets have long 
strands of fiber in the torn areas that are easily accessible by the juvenile dogs. Frayed edges and long fiber strands can 
be injurious to the dogs as they could ingest the material or cause entrapment of the juvenile dogs. All surfaces must be 
maintained on a regular basis. Surfaces of housing facilities - including houses, dens, and other furniture-type fixtures and 
objects within the facility - that cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized, must be replaced when worn or soiled.  
 
Correct by 16 December 2025 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the program of veterinary care for sampling and testing of intestinal parasites. The facility has 
not performed fecal sampling according to the schedule described in the program of veterinary care. The last recorded 
results for fecal sampling provided by the facility were reported on 18 January 2024. The facility representative stated this 
is usually performed during the annual kennel exam but could not provide a record of the sampling in 2025. APHIS 
personnel spoke with the office of the Attending Veterinarian who stated no fecal sampling was conducted in 2025. The 
program of veterinary care states fecal exams will be performed annually on 10% of the animals for intestinal parasites.  
Failure to follow the parasite control program approved by the attending veterinarian may not properly protect the dogs 
from parasites and may allow illness to go undetected and untreated, which may cause pain and unnecessary discomfort 
to the dogs. The facility must follow the parasite control testing schedule approved by the attending veterinarian to protect 
the dogs from parasites and other pests (worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) and have the dogs tested annually.  
Correct by 31 January 2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
 n
